(6/6) to be used by all students within the course as additional learning resources for the last phase of their term project work. Comments?
(5/6) which will be peer-reviewed and then place all students papers in a shared space within #CanvasLMS during the term...
(4/6) So, the 'partially open' approach I will try this term is having students choose a UX topic of interest, write summary articles...
(3/6) but find this process a daunting one to do properly within 13 weeks of a third year Computer Science UX design course.
(2/6) For example, I love the (pedagogical) approach of students editing Wikipedia articles in the open for a writing assignment...
(1/6) I myself often fall into the trap of looking at educational resources/activities in terms of 'closed' vs. 'open'.
Next rant: the importance of positioning 'open' as a gradient versus a binary switch.

The Grav Course Hub enables tech-savvy educators to use the open @getgrav platform along with the LMS to reach unmet pedagogical & UX goals.
Ok, so creating a problem statement of your product with 140 characters is pretty tricky but a worthy exercise. Here's what I've got so far:
#GravEdu is the hashtag for tweets about the use of the modern flat-file (no-database) CMS @getgrav in Higher Ed. https://t.co/VuG3m4D7q1
New Post: A Few Thoughts About Who the Grav Course Hub is Designed For https://t.co/KE7mQCTGxn #D2L #Blackboard #CanvasLMS #Moodle #GravEdu

(10/10) Explore a demo of the Grav Course Hub at https://t.co/qTgCdG6ZPM and read the Getting Started Guide https://t.co/L4vgd29InC
#GravEdu

(9/10) For educators who want a better multi-device user experience for their students and themselves.
#GravEdu

(8/10) For educators who want to reuse content in different contexts of the same course, and also between multiple related courses.
#GravEdu

(7/10) For educators who want students to actively shape their shared online environment.
#GravEdu

(6/10) For educators who want to have more control of the online environment for their students and themselves.
#GravEdu

(5/10) For educators who want to provide access to their course and materials beyond the scope of term start and end dates.
#GravEdu

(4/10) For educators who want to provide their course and materials in the open but still keep sensitive student data in the LMS.
#GravEdu

(3/10) For educators who have unmet pedagogical goals due to the constraints of their LMS.
#GravEdu

(2/10) The @getgrav Course Hub is designed for moderately tech-savvy educators with the following needs:
#GravEdu

(1/10) So, just who is the open source Grav Course Hub designed for anyway?
#GravEdu

(8/8) Existing LMSs/CMSs often prevent content from being globally searched and replaced by authors. Content as FILES removes this issue.
(7/8) Existing LMSs/CMSs often require IT involvement for content or server migration, while a flat-file CMS only needs simple FILE COPYING.
(6/8) Existing LMSs/CMSs can often only be edited by pre-defined interfaces. A flat-file CMS gives authors and contributors tool CHOICE.
(5/8) Existing LMSs/CMSs are often database-driven which can impact PERFORMANCE with even the simplest content presentation tasks.
(4/8) Existing LMSs/CMSs are often blob-based, where each page is a single blog of content rather than modular/reusable CONTENT CHUNKS.
(3/8) Existing LMSs/CMSs most only support limited collaborative editing. Content and logic are BOTH editable collaboratively (i.e. GitHub).
(2/8) Existing LMSs/CMSs controlled by IT are often locked down. A site built with a flat-file CMS enables easier HTML/CSS CUSTOMIZATIONS.
(1/8) Here are the top 7 problems the @getgrav flat-file (no database) CMS has solved for me as an educator trying to move beyond the LMS:

(3/3) What to flip the LMS with?
An open + collaborative platform, where course participants can shape and contribute to their online space.

(2/3) Why flip the LMS?
‚úì to reach unmet pedagogical goals
‚úì to increase access, sharing, and collaboration
‚úì a better experience for all
(1/3) A flipped-LMS is where a platform chosen by the instructor, under their full control, serves as an alternative front-end to the LMS.

(4/4) So, an alternative? Perhaps "experience design for [domain]". From my perspective it's embedding the full-stack of UX into any domain.
(3/4) Learner experience design also assumes the audience in question are just learners, which is not the case (they are people).
(2/4) Too often people think of LX separate from, or a subset of, UX design, but this is misleading and certainly not what I have found.
(1/4) While I've been using the term "learner experience (LX) design" myself for several years, I am finding it more and more problematic.

(7/7) Based on these results a flipped-LMS approach shows a lot of promise for both my students (and myself), but work remains to be done.
(6/7) 6% of CMPT-363 students were undecided with regards to the same overall course companion design being used for other courses.
(5/7) 12.5% of CMPT-363 students indicated they would not want to see the same overall course companion design used for other courses.
(4/7) 81.5% students in CMPT-363 survey indicated they would like to see the same overall course companion design used for other courses.

(2/7) Given this challenge, it's critical that students (& instructors!) significantly benefit from what a flipped-LMS approach can provide.
(1/7) The #1 flipped-LMS challenge? Friction between the systems, especially when students would naturally prefer one system for everything.

Many key strengths of #CanvasLMS stand out with a flipped-LMS approach: peer reviews, discussions, student calendar, assignments and grades.
Example flipped-LMS approach w. #CanvasLMS http://t.co/I7fZ1cnbn3 In the words of Thomas Edison, vision without execution is hallucination.

When thinking about "flipping" a LMS, consider all 3 elements of Learner Experience Design:
‚úÖUX Design
‚úÖEducational Design
‚úÖTech Development
If your LMS supports deep-linking (i.e. links will flow through to targets with user authentication) then any instructor can "flip" the LMS.
When does a flipped-LMS make sense? When BENEFIT > EFFORT for students and instructors. Both are contextual and audience specific.
When taking a flipped-LMS approach it is critical that a single URL can be provided to students as the entry point to all tools/resources.

@gcoulthard Just posted a series of user stories which serve as the requirements for my workflow - are these relatable to you too? Thanks!
(6/6) As a teacher, I want to quickly update the live course companion site so that I spend a minimum of time with non-productive tasks.
(5/6) As a teacher, I want to control updates to the course companion site so that the risk of not being available to students is minimized.
(4/6) As a teacher, I want to share course companion content and code so that others can reuse and adapt the materials to their own needs.
(3/6) As a teacher, I want to enable my students to be contributors to the course companion so we can all benefit from their knowledge.
(2/6) As a teacher, I want to be able to edit the course companion on any of my devices so I can make changes when most convenient for me.

6) Existing LMS's/CMS's often prevent content from being globally searched and replaced by authors. Content as FILES removes these barriers.
@6sigma @getgrav Hey, I am really glad to hear that! Grav has been really awesome to work with, be sure to check out the Gitter.im room too.
5) Existing LMS's/CMS's often require IT involvement for content or server migration, while a flat-file CMS only needs simple FILE COPYING.
Here is a 5th problem that a flat-file CMS solved for me as an individual instructor:
Want to see an example of the flat-file CMS @getgrav being used? Explore my latest multi-device course companion at http://t.co/V4gRb8kA5t
4) Existing LMS's/CMS's can often only be edited by pre-defined interfaces. A flat-file CMS gives authors and contributors tool CHOICE.
3) Existing LMS's/CMS's are often database-driven which can impact performance on even the simplest content presentation tasks. SPEED = UX.
2) Existing LMS's/CMS's are often blob-based, where each page is a single blog of content rather than MODULAR/REUSABLE content chunks.
1) Existing LMS's/CMS's often only support limited collaborative editing. Content AND logic are both editable collaboratively (i.e. GitHub).
My current fav. open source flat-file CMS is @getgrav, which has solid docs, a really helpful community & solves the following 4 problems:
Flat-file CMS: A modern, modular and multi-device CMS which stores content as files (i.e. not in a database) using industry-standard formats
Let's start talking about what flat-file CMS's bring to the table for instructors AND students from the viewpoint of problems they solve.

What do multi-device experiences mean to you?
#5 We need to think about APIs and content structure as well as multiple screens
#4 Devices will not just vary in terms of displays, but also interactions, posture, and privacy
#3 People will expect the same functionality and content regardless of device
#2 Device transitions mid-task are bound to be attempted
Multi-device experiences mean that‚Ä¶ #1 People can choose the specific device best suited to the task at hand
But being multi-device REALLY means being more available!
Being mobile really means being available.
